thread.title: China eases rules for foreign investors in interbank market
thread.title_full: China eases rules for foreign investors in interbank market | South China Morning Post

author: Reuters
title: China eases rules for foreign investors in interbank market
text:
Beijing has relaxed rules for some long-term foreign investors in its interbank market by removing the limits on the sizes of investment, a move that could deepen the country's nascent financial market.
But some investors warned it might be some time yet before the measure, which came less than a week after the central government intervened heavily in its stock market to prevent a meltdown, took effect and increased investment opportunities.
Foreign central banks, financial institutions and sovereign wealth funds that were approved investors in the interbank market could now buy or sell bonds, bond forwards, interest rate swaps and conduct bond repurchases, the central bank said.
The rules are effective from Tuesday.
These foreign investors "should be long-term investors" and could decide for themselves how much to invest, the People's Bank of China said in a statement on its website.
"This is mainly about removing limits on sizes of investment for these foreign investors," said a bond trader in Shanghai.
Given that trades done by foreign investors require counterparties, some of which face restrictions on the sizes of their investments, a banker at a medium-sized mainland bank said it could be a long time yet before the market was actually freed up.
Granting foreign investors greater access to the capital markets is a long-running theme in the country's quest to reform its economy and turn into one more reliant on free markets, and less dependent on central planning.
Sources said in March the government was set to relax its rules for trading by foreigners in its Shanghai-based interbank market, by making it simpler for them to get quotas for their investments.
But its reform credentials suffered after it waded into the stock market last week to support share prices with strong-arm tactics, including telling brokerages to buy stocks and barring some firms from selling their shares.
This article appeared in the South China Morning Post print edition as Mainland eases rules for foreign investors
